t: Nahum 1
A*p prophecy concerning Nineveh. The book of the vision of Nahum the Elkoshite.
The Lord’s Anger Against Nineveh
The*pn Lord*s is a jealous and avenging God; the*ld Lord*s takes vengeance and is filled with wrath. The*ln Lord*s takes vengeance on his foes and*ld vents his wrath against his enemies.
The*ln Lord*s is slow to anger but great in power; the*ld Lord*s will not leave the guilty unpunished. His*ln way is in the whirlwind and the storm, and*ld clouds are the dust of his feet.
He*ln rebukes the sea and dries it up; he*ld makes all the rivers run dry. Bashan*ln and Carmel wither and*ld the blossoms of Lebanon fade.
The*ln mountains quake before him and*ld the hills melt away. The*ln earth trembles at his presence, the*ld world and all who live in it.
Who*ln can withstand his indignation? Who*ld can endure his fierce anger? His*ln wrath is poured out like fire; the*ld rocks are shattered before him.
The*pn Lord*s is good, a*ld refuge in times of trouble. He*ln cares for those who trust in him,
but*ld with an overwhelming flood he*ln will make an end of Nineveh; he*ld will pursue his foes into the realm of darkness.
Whatever*pn they plot against the Lord*s he*ld will bring to an end; trouble*ld will not come a second time.
They*ln will be entangled among thorns and*ld drunk from their wine; they*ld will be consumed like dry stubble.
From*ln you, Nineveh, has one come forth who*ld plots evil against the Lord*s and*ld devises wicked plans.
This*p is what the Lord*s says: “Although*pn they have allies and are numerous, they*ld will be destroyed and pass away. Although*ln I have afflicted you, Judah, I*ld will afflict you no more.
Now*ln I will break their yoke from your neck and*ld tear your shackles away.”

The*pn Lord*s has given a command concerning you, Nineveh: “You*ld will have no descendants to bear your name. I*ln will destroy the images and idols that*ld are in the temple of your gods. I*ln will prepare your grave, for*ld you are vile.”

Look,*pn there on the mountains, the*ld feet of one who brings good news, who*ld proclaims peace! Celebrate*ln your festivals, Judah, and*ld fulfill your vows. No*ln more will the wicked invade you; they*ld will be completely destroyed.
Nahum 2
Nineveh to Fall
An*pn attacker advances against you, Nineveh. Guard*ld the fortress, watch*ld the road, brace*ld yourselves, marshal*ld all your strength!
The*pn Lord*s will restore the splendor of Jacob like*ld the splendor of Israel, though*ln destroyers have laid them waste and*ld have ruined their vines.
The*pn shields of the soldiers are red; the*ld warriors are clad in scarlet. The*ln metal on the chariots flashes on*ld the day they are made ready; the*ld spears of juniper are brandished.
The*ln chariots storm through the streets, rushing*ld back and forth through the squares. They*ln look like flaming torches; they*ld dart about like lightning.
Nineveh*pn summons her picked troops, yet*ld they stumble on their way. They*ln dash to the city wall; the*ld protective shield is put in place.
The*ln river gates are thrown open and*ld the palace collapses.
It*ln is decreed that Nineveh be*ld exiled and carried away. Her*ln female slaves moan like doves and*ld beat on their breasts.
Nineveh*ln is like a pool whose*ld water is draining away. “Stop!*ln Stop!” they cry, but*ld no one turns back.
Plunder*ln the silver! Plunder*ld the gold! The*ln supply is endless, the*ld wealth from all its treasures!
She*ln is pillaged, plundered, stripped! Hearts*ld melt, knees give way, bodies*ld tremble, every face grows pale.
Where*pn now is the lions’ den, the*ld place where they fed their young, where*ln the lion and lioness went, and*ld the cubs, with nothing to fear?
The*ln lion killed enough for his cubs and*ld strangled the prey for his mate, filling*ln his lairs with the kill and*ld his dens with the prey.

“I*pn am against you,” declares*ld the Lord*s Almighty. “I*ln will burn up your chariots in smoke, and*ld the sword will devour your young lions. I*ld will leave you no prey on the earth. The*ln voices of your messengers will*ld no longer be heard.”
Nahum 3
Woe to Nineveh
Woe*pn to the city of blood, full*ld of lies, full*ln of plunder, never*ld without victims!
The*ln crack of whips, the*ld clatter of wheels, galloping*ln horses and*ld jolting chariots!
Charging*ln cavalry, flashing*ld swords and*ld glittering spears! Many*ln casualties, piles*ld of dead, bodies*ln without number, people*ld stumbling over the corpses—
all*ln because of the wanton lust of a prostitute, alluring,*ld the mistress of sorceries, who*ln enslaved nations by her prostitution and*ld peoples by her witchcraft.
“I*pn am against you,” declares the Lord*s Almighty. “I*ld will lift your skirts over your face. I*ln will show the nations your nakedness and*ld the kingdoms your shame.
I*ln will pelt you with filth, I*ld will treat you with contempt and*ld make you a spectacle.
All*ln who see you will flee from you and say, ‘Nineveh*ld is in ruins—who will mourn for her?’ Where*ld can I find anyone to comfort you?”
Are*pn you better than Thebes, situated*ld on the Nile, with*ld water around her? The*ln river was her defense, the*ld waters her wall.
Cush*ln and Egypt were her boundless strength; Put*ld and Libya were among her allies.
Yet*ln she was taken captive and*ld went into exile. Her*ln infants were dashed to pieces at*ld every street corner. Lots*ln were cast for her nobles, and*ld all her great men were put in chains.
You*ln too will become drunk; you*ld will go into hiding and*ld seek refuge from the enemy.
All*pn your fortresses are like fig trees with*ld their first ripe fruit; when*ln they are shaken, the*ld figs fall into the mouth of the eater.
Look*ln at your troops— they*ld are all weaklings. The*ln gates of your land are*ld wide open to your enemies; fire*ld has consumed the bars of your gates.
Draw*pn water for the siege, strengthen*ld your defenses! Work*ln the clay, tread*ld the mortar, repair*ld the brickwork!
There*ln the fire will consume you; the*ld sword will cut you down— they*ld will devour you like a swarm of locusts. Multiply*ln like grasshoppers, multiply*ld like locusts!
You*ln have increased the number of your merchants till*ld they are more numerous than the stars in the sky, but*ln like locusts they strip the land and*ld then fly away.
Your*ln guards are like locusts, your*ld officials like swarms of locusts that*ld settle in the walls on a cold day— but*ln when the sun appears they fly away, and*ld no one knows where.
King*pn of Assyria, your shepherds slumber; your*ld nobles lie down to rest. Your*ln people are scattered on the mountains with*ld no one to gather them.
Nothing*ln can heal you; your*ld wound is fatal. All*ln who hear the news about you clap*ld their hands at your fall, for*ln who has not felt your*ld endless cruelty?
